questions.text: A 32 year old lady is undergoing evaluation for polycystic ovary syndrome. Her sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) is low. The decrease in sex hormone-binding globulin will have the maximum effect on which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
The decrease in sex hormone-binding globulin will have the maximum effect on testosterone.

Around 98% of the circulating testosterone is bound to plasma proteins such as sex hormone-binding globulin (65%) and albumin. So, the decrease in sex-hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) or gonadal steroid-binding globulin (GBG) will have the maximum effect on testosterone levels by increasing the levels of its free form.

Therefore patients with polycystic ovary syndrome will show features of hyperandrogenism (due to elevated free testosterone).

questions.text: Sertoli cells in testes have receptors for______
questions.solution:
Sertoli cells express FSH receptor, whereas Leydig cell express LH receptor

Sertoli cells are the true epithelial cells of the seminiferous epithelium and extend from basal lamina to the lumen.

Functions of Sertoli cells:

  • Express FSH receptor and androgen receptor.
  • Forms the blood-testis barrier.
  • Surround the sperm cells and provide structural support within the epithelium.
  • Guide sperm cells towards the lumen as they advance to later stages of spermatogenesis.
  • Produce inhibin and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS).
  • Produce androgen-binding proteins that maintain high androgen levels within the lumen of the seminiferous tubules and the proximal part of the male reproductive tract.
  • Perform phagocytic function by engulfing residual bodies (cytoplasm shed by spermatozoa during spermiogenesis) and dead sperm cells.
  • Express aromatase, which converts testosterone to potent estrogen.

questions.text: The negative feedback mechanism involving the Sertoli cells causes _____
questions.solution:
The negative feedback mechanism involving the Sertoli cells causes ↓FSH.

FSH stimulates inhibin production by the Sertoli cells. This inhibin inhibits FSH production by directly acting on the anterior pituitary. Thus, inhibin keeps FSH levels within a set point.

questions.text: In men, LH controls secretion of______
questions.solution:
In men, LH controls the secretion of testosterone.

LH stimulates Leydig cells to secrete testosterone, which in turn inhibits LH by a negative feedback mechanism. FSH stimulates Sertoli cells to secrete inhibin, which in turn inhibits FSH by a negative feedback mechanism.

Testosterone inhibits LH secretion by acting directly on the anterior pituitary and by inhibiting the secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus. Inhibin acts directly on the anterior pituitary to inhibit FSH secretion.

FSH also stimulates the secretion of ABP (androgen-binding protein) and inhibin. FSH and androgens maintain the gametogenic function of the testes. Hypothalamic lesions in animals and hypothalamic disease in humans lead to atrophy of the testes and loss of their function.

questions.text: Testosterone production is mainly contributed by ______
questions.solution:
Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells.

Testosterone is synthesized from cholesterol in the Leydig cells and also from androstenedione secreted by the adrenal cortex.

The diagnosis of testosterone deficiency should be made only on the basis of clinical signs and symptoms consistent with androgen deficiency, and consistently subnormal serum testosterone concentrations at 8 to 10 AM on three occasions. 

Testosterone has been used to treat primary or secondary hypogonadism in adult men.

questions.text: All of the following are androgens except______
questions.solution:
17α hydroxy-progesterone is a progestin, not androgen.

The term androgen means any steroid hormone that has masculinizing effects.  Testosterone, Dihydrotestosterone, androstenedione, and dehydroepiandrosterone are androgens.

The sites of production:

  • Testes.
  • Adrenal gland.
  • Ovary (not significant).
  • Tumors of the adrenal androgen-producing cells etc.

Both in the testes and in the adrenals, the androgens can be synthesized either from cholesterol or directly from acetyl coenzyme A.

Related Pearl: Biosynthesis Pathway for Androgen Synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following cells secrete anti mullerian hormone?
questions.solution:
(Anti Mullerian Hormone) is secreted by both sertoli cells and granulosa cells.

Sertoli cells produce Anti Mullerian Hormone (Mullerian inhibitory substance) during development. It induces the regression of the mullerian duct that is programmed to give rise to a female reproductive tract.

Granulosa cells of the ovary produce AMH during the reproductive years. It limits the formation of primary follicles by inhibiting excessive follicular recruitment by FSH.

questions.text: The blood-testis barrier is formed by______

choices.text: Tight junctions between adjacent leydig cells
Tight junctions between adjacent sertoli cells

questions.solution:
The blood-testis barrier is formed by the tight junctions between adjacent sertoli cells.

This Sertoli-Sertoli cell tight junctions divide the seminiferous epithelium into 2 compartments:

  • Basal compartment - contains the spermatogonia and early-stage primary spermatocytes.
  • Adluminal compartment - contains later-stage primary spermatocytes and all subsequent stages of sperm cells.

It imparts a selective permeability, allowing few substances such as testosterone to cross but preventing noxious substances that might damage the developing sperm. It also protects sperms from antibodies by creating a specialized, immunologically safe microenvironment for developing sperm.

 

BELOW DIAGRAM - 

1 basal lamina, 2 spermatogonia, 3 spermatocyte 1st order, 4 spermatocyte 2nd order, 5 spermatid, 6 mature spermatid, 7 Sertoli cell, 8 tight junctions(Blood- Testis Barrier)

questions.text: Spermiogenesis refers to_______

choices.text: Formation of secondary spermatocyte from primary spermatocyte

questions.solution:
Spermiogenesis refers to the formation of spermatozoa from spermatids.

Spermiogenesis is a process by which there is a formation of extremely specialized mobile spermatozoa from spermatids. This process requires extensive remodeling or packaging of cell elements. It occurs in the recesses formed by invaginations of the sertoli cell plasma membrane.

Maturation from spermatids to spermatozoa depends on androgen acting on sertoli cells. When sperm maturation is complete, the cytoplasm of the sertoli cell around sperm retracts and sperms are released into the lumen to be bathed by the luminal fluid.

The following changes occur during the formation ofspermatozoafrom spermatids :

  • The nucleus becomes eccentric and decreases in size, and the chromatin becomes condensed.
  • The cytoplasmic content is redistributed and discarded.
  • The acrosome buds from the golgi apparatus.
  • The centrioles migrate to the caudal pole and form a long axial filament made of microtubules. This becomes the axoneme or major portion of the tail.

Spermiation is the release of the sperm from the sertoli cells. During spermiation, most of the remaining cytoplasm is shed in the form of residual bodies.

Spermatogenesis refers to the formation of spermatozoa from spermatogonia.

questions.text: Development of spermatozoa from spermatogonium takes how much time?
questions.solution:
The time required to produce mature spermatozoa from the earliest stage of spermatogonia is 65 to 70 days.

Since several developmental stages of spermatogenic cells occur during this time frame, the stages are collectively known as the spermatogenic cycle.

questions.text: Spermatogenesis is maintained by which hormone?
questions.solution:
All three of them (testosterone, FSH, LH) are required for spermatogenesis.

Pulses of hypothalamic GnRH stimulate the anterior pituitary to secrete FSH and LH, which then act on the testes

FSH acts on the Sertoli cells to stimulate spermatogenesis and inhibin secretion. LH acts on the Leydig cells to stimulate testosterone secretion. Testosterone, acting locally on the Sertoli cells, is essential for maintaining spermatogenesis.

questions.text: Role of growth hormone in spermatogenesis  is _______
questions.solution:
The growth hormone specifically promotes the early division of spermatogonia.

Hormonal factors that stimulate spermatogenesis:

  • Testosterone, secreted by the Leydig cells of the testis, is essential for growth and division of the testicular germinal cells, which is the first stage in forming sperm.
  • Luteinizing hormone, secreted by the anterior pituitary gland, stimulates the Leydig cells to secrete testosterone.
  • Follicle-stimulating hormone, secreted by the anterior pituitary gland, stimulates the Sertoli cells. Without this stimulation, the spermiogenesis will not occur.
  • Estrogens, formed from testosterone by the Sertoli cells when stimulated by FSH, are also essential for spermiogenesis.
  • Growth hormone is necessary for controlling the background metabolic functions of the testes. It specifically promotes early division of the spermatogonia themselves. In its absence, as in pituitary dwarfs, spermatogenesis is severely deficient or absent, thus causing infertility.

questions.text: Which of the following provides a negative feedback in spermatogenesis?
questions.solution:
Negative feedback in spermatogenesis is by inhibin.

FSH stimulates inhibin production by the Sertoli cells. This inhibin inhibits FSH production by directly acting on the anterior pituitary. 

LH stimulates Leydig cells to secrete testosterone, which in turn inhibits LH. Testosterone inhibits LH secretion by acting directly on the anterior pituitary and by inhibiting the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is being evaluated for suspected infertility. His semen analysis shows a decrease in sperm count and motility. On physical examination, a 'bag of worms'-like structure is palpated in his scrotum, suggestive of varicocele. Which of the following is the most likely reason behind his decreased sperm count?

choices.text: Lowered scrotal temperature, compared to core temperature
Rise in scrotal temperature, compared to core temperature

questions.solution:
The most likely reason behind decreased sperm count in this patient is rise in scrotal temperature, secondary to varicocoele.

Normally, the testes occupy the scrotum, which lies outside the body cavity and is maintained at 35° to 36°C, or 1° to 2°C below body temperature. This lower temperature is essential for normal spermatogenesis. It is maintained by a countercurrent arrangement of testicular arteries and veins, which facilitates heat exchange. 

Enlarged veins around the testes, called varicoceles, cause infertility by raising the temperature in the scrotum and decreasing sperm production.

questions.text: Sperm acquires motility in______
questions.solution:
Sperm is stored in the epididymis, where they undergo a process of maturation before they are capable of progressive motility and fertilization.

Changes during the sperm maturation in the epididymis:

  • Progressive increase in forward motility  
  • Increase ability to fertilize  
  • Maturation of acrosome  
  • Molecular reorganization of plasma membrane: Lipid (stabilization of plasma membrane) protein (shedding as well as the acquisition of new proteins)
  • Ability to bind to zona pellucida  
  • Acquisition of receptors for proteins of the zona pellucida  
  • Increase disulfide bond between cysteine residues in sperm nucleoproteins  
  • Topographic regionalization of glycosidic residues  
  • Accumulation of mannosylated residues on periacrosomal plasma membrane  
  • Decreased cytoplasm and cell volume

questions.text: At which location does the capacitation of sperm take place?
questions.solution:
Capacitation of sperm takes place in uterine tubes.

Once ejaculated into the female genital tract, the spermatozoa move up the uterus to the isthmus of the uterine tubes, where they slow down and undergo final conditioning called capacitation. 

This process involves two components:

  • Increasing the motility of the spermatozoa
  • Facilitating their preparation for the acrosomal reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following factors increases sperm motility?
questions.solution:
Sperm motility is increased by vaginal secretions.

On coming in contact with the fluids of the female genital tract, multiple changes occur that activate the sperm for the final processes of fertilization. These collective changes are called capacitation of the spermatozoa, which normally requires from 1 to 10 hours.

The following changes are believed to occur:

  • The uterine and fallopian tube fluids wash away the various inhibitory factors that suppress sperm activity in the male genital ducts.
  • While the spermatozoa remain in the fluid of the male genital ducts, they are continually exposed to many floating vesicles from the seminiferous tubules containing large amounts of cholesterol. This cholesterol is continually added to the cellular membrane covering the sperm acrosome, toughening this membrane and preventing the release of its enzymes.
  • After ejaculation, the sperm deposited in the vagina swim away from the cholesterol vesicles upward into the uterine cavity, and they gradually lose much of their other excess cholesterol during the next few hours. In doing so, the membrane at the head of the sperm (the acrosome) becomes much weaker.
  • The membrane of the sperm also becomes much more permeable to calcium ions, so calcium now enters the sperm in abundance and changes the activity of the flagellum, giving it a powerful whiplash motion in contrast to its previously weak undulating motion. In addition, the calcium ions cause changes in the cellular membrane that cover the leading edge of the acrosome, making it possible for the acrosome to release its enzymes rapidly and easily as the sperm penetrates the granulosa cell mass surrounding the ovum, and even more so as it attempts to penetrate the zona pellucida of the ovum.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man suffering from prostate cancer is undergoing long-term androgen deprivation therapy. He is being treated with long acting GnRH agonist. After prolonged injection of GnRH, which of the following will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Prolonged injection of GnRH will lead to decreased LH levels.

A constant administration of GnRH produces an initial agonistic action known as "flare", followed by a downregulation of GnRH receptors ( decrease in GnRH receptor concentration). This desensitizes pituitary to the action of GnRH and a hypogonadotropic-hypogonadal state is induced.

This is characterized by low LH, low FSH levels and thereby reduced testosterone production (i.e., chemical castration).

questions.text: The major contribution to semen is from which of the following organs?
questions.solution:
The major contribution to semen is from seminal vesicles.

The seminal vesicles contribute ~60-70% of the volume of semen. Apart from sperm, the remaining 20-40% represents epididymal fluids, as well as secretions of the prostate gland and bulbourethral glands.

The seminal plasma originates primarily from the accessory glands (the seminal vesicles, the prostate gland, and the bulbourethral glands).

questions.text: Normal pH of human semen is_____
questions.solution:
The normal pH of human semen is 7.4 (isotonic).

The pH in the lumen of the epididymis is relatively acidic (6.5 to 6.8) as the result of H+ secretion by clear cells that are analogous to intercalated cells in the nephron. Addition of the relatively alkaline secretions of the seminal vesicles raises the final pH of seminal plasma to between 7.2 and 7.8.

Spermatozoa generally tolerate alkalinity better than acidity.

A pH near neutrality or slightly higher is optimal for the motility and survival of sperm cells in humans and in other species as well.

questions.text: Prostaglandins in semen are secreted by which of the following organs?
questions.solution:
Prostaglandins in semen are secreted by seminal vesicle.

The seminal vesicles secrete fluid that is rich in fructose, citrate, prostaglandins, and fibrinogen.

The prostaglandins present in the seminal fluid may assist in fertilization in two ways:

  • Prostaglandins react with cervical mucus to make it more penetrable by sperm.
  • Prostaglandins induce peristaltic contractions in the female reproductive tract (i.e., the uterus and fallopian tubes) to propel the sperm up the tract.

questions.text: A couple is undergoing evaluation for their inability to conceive. In order to rule out male factor infertility, the consultant orders a semen analysis for the husband. Which of the following best estimates the normal sperm count in an adult?
questions.solution:
Normal sperm count on an average is 100 million/ml (90-120 million/mL).

Note: The WHO 2010 minimal criteria for semen analysis requires a minimum sperm count >15 million/mL or >40 million/per ejaculate.

questions.text: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization take place?
questions.solution: In humans, fertilization of the ovum by the sperm usually occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube.

questions.text: For how many hours does human sperm remain fertile in the female genital tract?
questions.solution:
After ejaculation, sperms have a maximal lifespan of 24-48 hours in the female genital tract.

The activity and rate of metabolism of sperm increase markedly with increas­ing temperature causing its life to be considerably shortened.

Sperm can be cryopreserved for years if agents such as glycerol are used to prevent ice crystal formation during freezing.

Note: The ovum remains viable and capable of being fertilized, probably no longer than 24 hours after it is expelled from the ovary.

questions.text: For how long does the ovum remain viable following ovulation?
questions.solution:
The ovum remains viable up to 24hours following ovulation.

If not fertilized, the ovum degenerates in the fallopian tube without leaving behind any trace after 24 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones has no role for the attainment of puberty?
questions.solution:
Insulin has no role in the attainment of puberty. GH, leptin and testosterone are all required for the onset of puberty.

The onset of puberty is marked by enhanced androgenic activity. The growth spurt of adolescent males is influenced by a complex interplay between androgens, growth hormone (GH), nutrition, and genetic factors.

Leptin, the satiety-producing hormone secreted by fat cells, may be the link between body weight and puberty.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is responsible for pubarche?
questions.solution:
Pubarche or the development of axillary and pubic hair is due to testosterone.

The growth of pubic and axillary hair in both sexes is primarily due to androgens.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones play a permissive role in the attainment of puberty?
questions.solution:
The hormone that plays a permissive role in the attainment of puberty is leptin.

It now appears that leptin may be the link between body weight and puberty. Leptin is a satiety-producing hormone secreted by adipocytes. High leptin levels reduce appetite and increase energy expenditure.

Evidence for which is given by:

  • Obese ob/ob mice that cannot make leptin are infertile, and their fertility is restored by injections of leptin.
  • Leptin treatment also induces precocious puberty in immature female mice.
  • However, the way that leptin fits into the overall control of puberty remains to be determined.

Leptin also accelerates GnRH pulsatility in neurons, fastening puberty.
